vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(accrualBlockNumber == 0 && borrowIndex == 0, "market may only be initialized once");
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == admin, "only admin may initialize the market");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: erc20-interface
vulnerability_findings.message:
EIP20NonStandardInterface (SimplePriceOracle.sol#117-179) has incorrect ERC20 function interface(s):
	-transfer (SimplePriceOracle.sol#143)
	-transferFrom (SimplePriceOracle.sol#157)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RToken._addReservesInternal (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2456-2468):
	External calls:
	- error = accrueInterest() (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2457-2458)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- totalReserves (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2464-2465)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RToken._reduceReserves (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2519-2529):
	External calls:
	- error = accrueInterest() (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2520-2521)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- totalReserves (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2526-2527)

vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RToken._setCointroller (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2388-2407):
	External calls:
	- require(bool,string)(newCointroller.isCointroller(),marker method returned false) (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2396-2397)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- cointroller (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2399-2400)

	- _setInterestRateModelFresh(newInterestRateModel) (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2591-2592)

RBep20.initialize (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2703-2718) does not use the value returned by external calls:

vulnerability_findings.name: shadowing-local
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: (MathError err, Exp memory fraction) = divScalarByExp(scalar, divisor);
vulnerability_findings.message:
Exponential.divScalarByExpTruncate.fraction (local variable @ SimplePriceOracle.sol#1105) shadows:
	- ExponentialNoError.fraction (function @ SimplePriceOracle.sol#977-979)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-benign
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RToken.borrowFresh (SimplePriceOracle.sol#1968-2032):
	External calls:
	- allowed = cointroller.borrowAllowed(address(this),borrower,borrowAmount) (SimplePriceOracle.sol#1970)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- accountBorrows (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2020)
	- accountBorrows (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2021)
	- totalBorrows (SimplePriceOracle.sol#2022)

	- symbol (SimplePriceOracle.sol#1281)

vulnerability_findings.name: solc-version
vulnerability_findings.message:
Detected issues with version pragma in SimplePriceOracle.sol:
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (SimplePriceOracle.sol#3): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (SimplePriceOracle.sol#77): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (SimplePriceOracle.sol#110): it allows old versions

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 120)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.number environment variable.
The block.number environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
Classification: SWC-120
